data: Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) NSTEMI and Unstable Angina - Initial Management
For ongoing management, please refer to CARD NSTEMI and Unstable Angina - Ongoing Management (Module)
Refer to Non-ST-Elevation Angina Management Algorithm
Calculate GRACE risk score on all NSTEMI patients: GRACE ACS Risk Model Calculator
Calculate Crusade bleeding risk score on all NSTEMI patients: Crusade Bleeding Risk Score Calculator
Ensure patient has received a total dose of ASA 160 mg in past 12 hours
160 mg, PO, once, drug form: tab-chew, first dose: STAT
80 mg, PO, once, drug form: tab-chew, first dose: STAT

Routine pre-treatment with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor in NSTEMI-ACS patients, in whom an early invasive management is planned and coronary anatomy is not known, is NOT RECOMMENDED given the lack of established benefit. However for patients with a planned delayed invasive management strategy (greater than 24 hours), P2Y12 receptor inhibitor may be considered based on thrombotic and bleed risk; AND likelihood of requiring urgent cardiac surgery in the next 5 days

- For patients requiring long term anticoagulation, clopidogrel is preferred  - Avoid clopidogrel and tricagrelor in patients at high risk for bleeding  - Avoid ticagrelor in patients with severe bradycardia (heart rate less than 50 bpm)  - Hold ticagrelo
180 mg, PO, once, drug form: tab, first dose: STAT
On ticagrelor in the past consecutive 7 days AND low likelihood of urgent cardiac surgery in the next 5 days
90 mg, PO, once, drug form: tab, first dose: STAT
Clopidogrel loading dose is only for patients not previously on clopidogrel for past 7 consecutive days  AND low likelihood of urgent cardiac surgery in the next 5 days
300 mg, PO, once, drug form: tab, first dose: STAT
On clopidogrel in the past consecutive 7 days AND low likelihood of urgent cardiac surgery in the next 5 days
75 mg, PO, once, drug form: tab, first dose: STAT

Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa Inhibitor (eptifibatide) therapy may be considered in very high risk patients awaiting PCI who have ongoing or recurrent ischemia despite dual antiplatelet therapy and an anticoagulant. Discuss with interventional or local cardiologist prior to ordering
No anticoagulation preferred if patient has a known bleeding disorder, or patient has a history of bleeding
No anticoagulation preferred, patient has a known bleeding disorder
No anticoagulation preferred,  patient has a history of bleeding
If anticoagulation required, select heparin OR enoxaparin OR fondaparinux
Heparin infusion is preferred for patients expected to go to the cath lab within 48 hours; or for patients with impaired renal function. Reassess 48 hours after initiation
Enoxaparin is INDICATED for patients requiring inter-facility transfer; medically managed patients; low to moderate risk of bleeding
Enoxaparin is CONTRAINDICATED in a patient with a known eGFR of less than 30 mL/min or with suspected severe renal insufficiency. Use with caution and omit IV bolus if age greater than 75 years
1 mg/kg, subcutaneous, q12h, order duration: 8 day, drug form: inj, first dose: STAT
Fondaparinux is INDICATED for medically managed patients not expected to go to the Cardiac Catheterization lab in the next 7 days; moderate to high risk of bleeding
Fondaparinux is CONTRAINDICATED in a patient with a known eGFR of less than 30 mL/min or with suspected severe renal insufficiency. Not preferred if there is a possibility of PCI within 7 days
2.5 mg, subcutaneous, qPM, order duration: 8 day, drug form: syringe-inj, first dose: STAT

Avoid nitroglycerin if any of the following are present:  - SBP below 90 mmHg or if more than 30 mmHg drop from baseline  - Suspected right ventricular infarction  - Recent use of phosphodiesterase inhibitors: within 24 hours for sildenafil [VIAGRA] and vardenafil [LEVITRA] and within 48 hours for tadalafil [CIALIS]
1 spray, sublingual, q5min, PRN pain-chest, drug form: spray
nitroglycerin titratable infusion (0.2 mg/mL) in D5W standard
Titrate, IV, 10 mcg/min starting rate, 0 mcg/min minimum rate, 200 mcg/min maximum rate, titrate instructions: Titrate by 10 mcg/min, q5min PRN for symptoms of ischemia; maintain SPB above 90 mmHg
25 mg, PO, BID, drug form: tab, first dose: STAT
12.5 mg, PO, BID, drug form: tab, first dose: STAT
50 mg, PO, BID, drug form: tab, first dose: STAT
100 mg, PO, BID, drug form: tab, first dose: STAT
dose range: 1 to 5 mg, IV, q1min, PRN other (see comment), drug form: inj
5 mg, IV, q10min, PRN pain, drug form: inj
Whole Blood, Urgent, Collection: T;N, once
Basic Metabolic Panel (Lytes, Urea, Creat, Gluc)
POC Basic Metabolic Panel (Lytes, Urea, Creat, Gluc)
Whole Blood, Urgent, Collection: T;N, once
Whole Blood, Urgent, Collection: T;N, once
Whole Blood, Timed, Collection: T;N+180, once
Urinalysis Macroscopic (dipstick) with Microscopic if indicated
HIV 1/2 Antibody and p24 Antigen BCCDC
HIV 1/2 Antibody and p24 Antigen PHC
ED Consult to General Internal Medicine
Consider consultation with Patient Transfer Network
